title: Linear Quadratic Model
summary: The Linear Quadratic (LQ) model is the most widely used mathematical framework for describing the relationship between radiation dose and biological effect, fundamental for fractionation schemes and treatment planning.

content.text: The LQ model describes cell survival as S = e^(-αD - βD²), where α represents single-hit kill and β represents two-hit kill. The α/β ratio characterizes tissue radiosensitivity and determines optimal fractionation.

Late-responding normal tissues typically have low α/β ratios (1-5 Gy), while early-responding tissues and most tumors have high α/β ratios (8-15 Gy). This difference forms the basis for fractionated radiotherapy.
The LQ model has limitations at very high doses per fraction (>8-10 Gy) and doesn't account for repair, repopulation, reoxygenation, and redistribution during prolonged treatments.
Hypofractionated treatments benefit from low α/β ratio tissues more than high α/β ratio tissues, explaining the success of SBRT for many tumor types.
